commit_message:
update sphinx requirement

syncs sphinx dependency with global requirements.
It caps python 2 since sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

Change-Id: Ia4ad99c8201f48292c35e7b50604d1d87c467eb3

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: If9c46ca5a80128bb8c6a9bd9863c4c3305bae54c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 15:21:04.000000000', 'message': "Use upper constraints

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped python 2.7 and 3.4 support. Because osprofiler
uses global upper-constraints.txt only from Rocky,
job openstack-tox-py27 tries to install Sphinx 2.0.1 and fails [1] with:

 Downloading http://mirror.iad.rax.openstack.org/wheel/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/sphinx/Sphinx-2.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (3.2MB)
 ERROR: Sphinx requires Python '>=3.5' but the running Python is 2.7.12

Note: .[oslo.config] could be removed as the packages will be installed
perfectly and constrained without this and it breaks installation if
upper-constraints.txt is used anyway.

Note: patch adjusted to Pike

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/stable/queens/openstack-tox-py27/3d469d3/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-10_06_10_56_192617

Change-Id: Ife6bcaca347d914cb1fc7e2fe71665ea5c93ca80
(cherry picked from commit eff57e09b55aaf1f00b01c289526ceddefdf25d9)
"}]
commit_message:
Use upper constraints

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped python 2.7 and 3.4 support. Because osprofiler
uses global upper-constraints.txt only from Rocky,
job openstack-tox-py27 tries to install Sphinx 2.0.1 and fails [1] with:

 Downloading http://mirror.iad.rax.openstack.org/wheel/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/sphinx/Sphinx-2.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (3.2MB)
 ERROR: Sphinx requires Python '>=3.5' but the running Python is 2.7.12

Note: .[oslo.config] could be removed as the packages will be installed
perfectly and constrained without this and it breaks installation if
upper-constraints.txt is used anyway.

Note: patch adjusted to Pike

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/stable/queens/openstack-tox-py27/3d469d3/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-10_06_10_56_192617

Change-Id: Ife6bcaca347d914cb1fc7e2fe71665ea5c93ca80
(cherry picked from commit eff57e09b55aaf1f00b01c289526ceddefdf25d9)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-09 09:57:20.000000000', 'message': 'Stop tokens being invalid due to frenet rotation

Change-Id: If5476e5eaf75b155bdb9965bfb475242c4deb746
Fixes-Bug: 1809469
'}, {'created': '2019-05-09 10:29:39.000000000', 'message': "Stop tokens being invalid due to frenet rotation

Fixes-Bug: 1809469

Right now every controller rotates frenet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, this does mean we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:
This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

In crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day correctly staggered
across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently we three controllers we have this in keystone.conf:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (default is 3600)
[allow_expired_window = 172800] (default is two days)
[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key.
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html#how-should-i-approach-key-distribution

As each controller rotates once a day, and we want to keep things valid
for three days (token expiration + allow_expired_window), plus one
staging key to promote next time and one secondary key from last time.

Change-Id: If5476e5eaf75b155bdb9965bfb475242c4deb746
"}, {'created': '2019-05-09 11:29:13.000000000', 'message': "Stop tokens being invalid due to frenet rotation

Closes-Bug: #1809469

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, this does mean we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:
 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

In crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day correctly staggered
across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)
[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Keystone docs note:
   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_frequency) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Translating that to kolla-ansible:
   token_expiration = fernet_token_expiry (= 1 day)
   allowed_expired_window = 2 days (the default) = 2 * fernet_token_expiry
   rotation_frequency = fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers
   num_controllers = (groups['keystone'] | length)
So we get:
   max_active_keys =
     ((3 * fernet_token_expiry) / (fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers)) + 2
This simplifies out to:
   max_active_keys = 3 * num_controllers + 2

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

Change-Id: If5476e5eaf75b155bdb9965bfb475242c4deb746
"}, {'created': '2019-05-09 11:32:41.000000000', 'message': "Stop tokens being invalid due to frenet rotation

Closes-Bug: #1809469

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, this does mean we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:
 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

In crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day correctly staggered
across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)
[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Keystone docs note:
   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_frequency) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Translating that to kolla-ansible:
   token_expiration = fernet_token_expiry (= 1 day)
   allowed_expired_window = 2 days (the default) = 2 * fernet_token_expiry
   rotation_frequency = fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers
   num_controllers = (groups['keystone'] | length)
So we get:
   max_active_keys =
     ((3 * fernet_token_expiry) / (fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers)) + 2
This simplifies out to:
   max_active_keys = 3 * num_controllers + 2

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

Change-Id: If5476e5eaf75b155bdb9965bfb475242c4deb746
"}]
commit_message:
Stop tokens being invalid due to frenet rotation

Closes-Bug: #1809469

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, this does mean we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:
 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

In crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day correctly staggered
across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)
[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Keystone docs note:
   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_frequency) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Translating that to kolla-ansible:
   token_expiration = fernet_token_expiry (= 1 day)
   allowed_expired_window = 2 days (the default) = 2 * fernet_token_expiry
   rotation_frequency = fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers
   num_controllers = (groups['keystone'] | length)
So we get:
   max_active_keys =
     ((3 * fernet_token_expiry) / (fernet_token_expiry / num_controllers)) + 2
This simplifies out to:
   max_active_keys = 3 * num_controllers + 2

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

Change-Id: If5476e5eaf75b155bdb9965bfb475242c4deb746

commit_message:
Update heat-translator-1.3.1 for param values

If user provides parameter file while creating VNF using scaling policy,
earlier it was failing with error 'The Parameter was not provided". This issue
already fixed in heat-translator-1.3.1.
Update lower-constraints.txt and requirements.txt with the same.

Depends-On: I67b9f53ac4cc0e4318fb7d62ac3d389c8cafbab2o
Change-Id: Ie1a6d859f91d8ad2decaaa1606dda1858df782a0
Closes-Bug: #1823860
Closes-Bug: #1799683

subject: Do not avoid same node with INFINITY score
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8297, 'name': 'Sofer Athlan-Guyot', 'email': 'sathlang@redhat.com', 'username': 'chem'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 30126, 'name': 'Luca Miccini', 'email': 'lmiccini@redhat.com', 'username': 'lmiccini2'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:22:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30126, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

not super fond of having a stonith resource on the same node it is supposed to fence, but worth to have a safety net nonetheless.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-05-15 23:02:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2019-05-16 08:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

hum, not really by the book[1], where inf is recommanded, but I can see why it would make sense if the other node cannot have a successful fencing action, maybe the one concerned could.

But then, as we have to suppose that the concerned node has trouble communicating with the cluster, we take the "risk" of having two fencing operation on the same node. I guess it's an acceptable risk.

I hope we are not missing some false positive case where this could cause havoc, as for me I can't see one.

[1] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/crm_fencing.html'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-16 08:50:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> hum, not really by the book[1], where inf is recommanded, but I can
 > see why it would make sense if the other node cannot have a
 > successful fencing action, maybe the one concerned could.
 > 
 > But then, as we have to suppose that the concerned node has trouble
 > communicating with the cluster, we take the "risk" of having two
 > fencing operation on the same node. I guess it's an acceptable
 > risk.
 > 
 > I hope we are not missing some false positive case where this could
 > cause havoc, as for me I can't see one.
 > 
 > [1] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/crm_fencing.html

Correct, I discussed this with the cluster folks and they actually
suggested this. The risk is very minimal and whenever we should be in that
position we're likely in a desperate case anyways.

From Ken's mail:
"""
However that means they can *never* monitor or use the device,
even if they're the last node standing. It would be better to use a
negative but finite score in the constraint (-100000 or whatever). That
way a node can shoot itself in an extreme situation rather than let
things spiral out of control. Of course you now have zero availability,
but perhaps better than a smoking power supply.
"""

Regarding two fencing operations on the same node, note that ATM
concurrent fencing is disabled and is serialized (that is actually
a separate discussion I am having with the cluster folks in the IHA
context).

hth?'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2019-05-16 08:55:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 09:22:41.000000000', 'message': "Do not avoid same node with INFINITY score

Right now when we create a stonith resource we add the location
constraint as follows:
pcs constraint location stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781 avoids controller-0

This, by default, will create a location constraint with INFINITY score,
meaning that this stonith manifest will never ever be allowed to run on
controller-0 no matter what:

  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781
    Disabled on: controller-0 (score:-INFINITY) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781-controller-0--INFINITY)

This is not ideal because we still want to be able to run this stonith
resource on controller-0 if all else fails.
Let's tweak this stonith resource creation to use a very high score
(10000) so that, ultimately the stonith resource is allowed to run
on the same controlled node itself.

Tested and correctly got all location constraints set:
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400116021
    Disabled on: compute-0 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400116021-compute-0--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254002a5c13
    Disabled on: controller-0 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254002a5c13-controller-0--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254004d7139
    Disabled on: compute-1 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254004d7139-compute-1--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400b77dcc
    Disabled on: controller-1 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400b77dcc-controller-1--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781
    Disabled on: controller-2 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781-controller-2--10000)

Suggested-by: Ken Gaillot <kgaillot@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1829146
Change-Id: I95d11d85d61bddc6d8600f576801a42af79a6652
"}]
commit_message:
Do not avoid same node with INFINITY score

Right now when we create a stonith resource we add the location
constraint as follows:
pcs constraint location stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781 avoids controller-0

This, by default, will create a location constraint with INFINITY score,
meaning that this stonith manifest will never ever be allowed to run on
controller-0 no matter what:

  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781
    Disabled on: controller-0 (score:-INFINITY) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781-controller-0--INFINITY)

This is not ideal because we still want to be able to run this stonith
resource on controller-0 if all else fails.
Let's tweak this stonith resource creation to use a very high score
(10000) so that, ultimately the stonith resource is allowed to run
on the same controlled node itself.

Tested and correctly got all location constraints set:
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400116021
    Disabled on: compute-0 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400116021-compute-0--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254002a5c13
    Disabled on: controller-0 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254002a5c13-controller-0--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254004d7139
    Disabled on: compute-1 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-5254004d7139-compute-1--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400b77dcc
    Disabled on: controller-1 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400b77dcc-controller-1--10000)
  Resource: stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781
    Disabled on: controller-2 (score:-10000) (id:location-stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400bb6781-controller-2--10000)

Suggested-by: Ken Gaillot <kgaillot@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1829146
Change-Id: I95d11d85d61bddc6d8600f576801a42af79a6652

messages: [{'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-05-15 17:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-05-15 17:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-05-15 23:18:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:\n\nShaun, FYI, I made this change because OpenStack CI was pulling in a new version of Sphinx (2.0.1) which insists on Python 3 to a greater extent than - apparently - we have yet in this repo.  I played briefly with enabling more Python 3, but that produced more problems in the UTs and PEP8 validation.  So instead let's just take Sphinx out, given that we don't need it anyway."}, {'account_id': 19461, 'date': '2019-05-16 08:28:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Reduce the number of "on-xxx" evaluations

* Mistral evaluates expressions under "on-xxx" clauses more than
  once during the processing of a workflow. It's now been fixed by
  storing crucial information about the result of those expressions
  after it was first obtained in the DB.
* Added two boolean fields "has_next_tasks" and "error_handled" in
  the TaskExecution class and the required migration. These fields
  allow not to calculate expressions under "on-xxx" clauses many
  times which leads to reducing execution time in case of heavy
  expressions and/or their data contexts.
* Minor style changes.

Closes-Bug: #1824121
Change-Id: Ib236ba7a72d8e578f9c52460d2a7d8d4540f9c37

The default content-type is html, and under certain

comments added. Because this specific content is meant
to be parsed as json those extra html comments break the
modal.js code.

We can't set the content-type to json without rewriting parts of
modal.js, as it will will parse it into an object early and then

Change-Id: If5a9ee7fe4273dc368dec7767a55d4467bf6a1a7
Closes-bug: #1824484

commit_message:
Correctly set content-type for workflow response

The default content-type is html, and under certain
circumstances like devstack the html has some additional
comments added. Because this specific content is meant
to be parsed as json those extra html comments break the
modal.js code.

We can't set the content-type to json without rewriting parts of
modal.js, as it will will parse it into an object early and then
modal.js will fail as it attempts to parse an object into json.

Change-Id: If5a9ee7fe4273dc368dec7767a55d4467bf6a1a7
Closes-bug: #1824484

commit_message:
Adapt the client for the v2 API

This adds a v2 client class allowing to add support for upcoming
v2 API endpoints. The v2 client class implements all v1 endpoints.
The cloudkitty API version can be specified with the
"--os-rating-api-version" option or the "OS_RATING_API_VERSION"
environment variable.

Change-Id: If38730da3baed59c93543a08f8a4989f919611db

[{'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-12-24 13:12:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28695, 'date': '2018-12-25 14:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Ifat, I added some initial remarks to start further discussion regarding integration with Monasca.

In addition found nice piece of documentation [1] about naming conventions and common metric dimensions. It might be valuable for the spec. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/monasca-agent/blob/master/docs/MonascaMetrics.md#common-dimensions'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-12-25 17:12:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-12-25 17:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-12-25 17:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-01-04 16:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

I think this is a great start. I have a few curiosity questions and comments, but nothing to hold back the spec.

From the Monasca side, we can work to include resource ID in more metrics/alarms, but as noted there will not be a single resource id for all types of metrics.'}, {'account_id': 28695, 'date': '2019-01-05 18:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28695, 'date': '2019-01-05 19:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28695, 'date': '2019-01-05 19:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-07 08:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-07 08:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-08 09:40:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)

I'm sorry for the late reply.
I added some comments. Examples with typical alarm definitions will follow."}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-08 12:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2019-01-08 12:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-08 17:17:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-08 17:52:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-09 09:08:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-11 14:44:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-13 10:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-15 11:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-16 15:34:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28695, 'date': '2019-01-17 23:50:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I add a few loose considerations and conclusions.

1. Alarms should be raised at the possibly lowest-level in the Entity Graph

We should always aim to raise the alarm at the possibly lowest-level vertex in the Graph. For example, with the choice of raising an alarm on a virtual machine or on a volume that is attached to the machine, we should raise the alarm on the volume. In other words, if disk space is running out, the Root Cause is located in the disk volume, rather than in the virtual machine. VM cause may be deduced later on by the scenario (template), but the flexibility of propagating the alarms should be left to the operator. By adopting such approach, we enable operators to leverage alarm propagation in the Graph (key Vitrage feature and advantage) and model more advanced RCA scenarios. Connecting the alarm too high in the Graph causes that we omit resources that may be important from the RCA point of view.

2. Metrics can point to multiple resources in Vitrage Entity Graph at the same time

For some alarms and metrics we will have to choose from several resource vertices in the Entity Graph, to which an alarm vertex should be connected. For example, in case of disk or network metrics, we will have to choose between connecting alarm vertex to a virtual machine or to a disk/network device attached to the machine - map alarm to resource by instance_id vs. instance_id + device.

Ifat, please correct me if I am wrong. At the moment, such scenario will not occur, because there is no mechanism in Vitrage that would ensure presence of device vertices in the Graph. Such mechanism, due to the fact that the devices are hard to obtain and can dynamically change, would be difficult to implement and we should consider whether its development will be undertaken at all.

3. Where to raise compound alarms?

Compound alarms are problematic because they can map to several different vertices in the graph. For example, an alarm describing CPU and disk usage in its definition (expression: avg(cpu) > 80% or disk > 70%) will have two metrics in its object that can be mapped to both the virtual machine and the disk volume. In that case, one need to decide where the alarm should be raised. On the virtual machine? On the volume? On both? Anywhere? Maybe it should be raised at the lowest common vertex?'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-01-20 09:13:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi, thanks for the comments. 

> 1. Alarms should be raised at the possibly lowest-level in the
> Entity Graph

Definitely. But the lowest level depends on the datasources that the user has. For example, the user might or might not have a datasource that retrieves the network topology. The purpose of this spec is to define a configuration format that will allow any user to configure his own set of mapping rules. Maybe we can add a document with examples and best practices.


 > 2. Metrics can point to multiple resources in Vitrage Entity Graph
 > at the same time

Isn't it what you are talking about at #3 below?


 > For some alarms and metrics we will have to choose from several
 > resource vertices in the Entity Graph, to which an alarm vertex
 > should be connected. For example, in case of disk or network
 > metrics, we will have to choose between connecting alarm vertex to
 > a virtual machine or to a disk/network device attached to the
 > machine - map alarm to resource by instance_id vs. instance_id +
 > device.

I think that the administrator that configures Vitrage should make this decision and update the configuration file accordingly. 


 > Ifat, please correct me if I am wrong. At the moment, such scenario
 > will not occur, because there is no mechanism in Vitrage that would
 > ensure presence of device vertices in the Graph. Such mechanism,
 > due to the fact that the devices are hard to obtain and can
 > dynamically change, would be difficult to implement and we should
 > consider whether its development will be undertaken at all.

I did not fully understand. Are you talking about devices that are not part of the entity graph at the moment? one could, theoretically, write a new datasource for that (I don't know how easy the implementation would be). 
Basically I think that if the user has a datasource that retrieves a specific information, he should map the alarm to the right entity. If not, he can map the alarm to the vm for example. Of course the highest granularity is preferable. 

 
 > 3. Where to raise compound alarms?
 > 
 > Compound alarms are problematic because they can map to several
 > different vertices in the graph. For example, an alarm describing
 > CPU and disk usage in its definition (expression: avg(cpu) > 80% or
 > disk > 70%) will have two metrics in its object that can be mapped
 > to both the virtual machine and the disk volume. In that case, one
 > need to decide where the alarm should be raised. On the virtual
 > machine? On the volume? On both? Anywhere? Maybe it should be
 > raised at the lowest common vertex?

I already mentioned it in one of my previous comments. My suggestion is to distinguish between 'and' condition to 'or' condition. 

In case of an 'and' condition, I think we should connect the alarm to all relevant resources. This will require a small refactoring in Vitrage, since at the moment we assume there is a single resource for every alarm.

In case of an 'or' condition, we need to design a better solution. For example, a new kind of edge, or an 'on' edge with probability percentage, etc. This can be done at a later phase."}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-30 09:16:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-01-30 09:22:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> > 2. Metrics can point to multiple resources in Vitrage Entity
 > Graph
 > > at the same time
 > 
 > Isn't it what you are talking about at #3 below?

No, Bartosz refers to grouped alarms here, I reckon. Please compare the `Grouped simple alarm definition` examples."}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-05-02 16:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}]

If the default ContainerImagePrepare value is not doing the right thing for ceph then it should be fixed instead of adding workarounds here.

One option is to break out the ceph values[1] into their own top-level list entry so the exact upstream label/tag policy can be defined. 

I can come up with a WIP change for this as a start.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/branch/master/container-images/container_image_prepare_defaults.yaml#L26-L30'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-05-15 22:42:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, this is downstream. I'll see what is happening with the images there"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-05-15 23:00:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

I've suggested an alternative in https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707824#c2"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-05-16 01:00:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> I've suggested an alternative in https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707824#c2

Thank you Steve. I was looking for a way to exclude the Ceph container but you had already built that feature in with the includes excludes list. Francesco and I just didn't think to use it. I've suggested in the review of the proposed documentation change that an example like the one you've provided be included but for upstream.

Francesco, if you agree do you want to abandon this patch?

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659297"}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:29:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi John/Steve,
I was unaware about the include/exclude list, so in general I think the layering feature is what we need to handle this kind of scenarios.
So yes, at this point I think this patch could be abandoned, and maybe we can spend few more words in documentation to provide an example (on ceph side).'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

The upstream feature is already present and can be used to handle this scenario.'}]

commit_message:
Added image filter when tag_from_label mechanism is used

Some external projects like Ceph which are integrated with
TripleO  don't follow the defined tagging convention, so
with this review we  added a regex based filter to skip the
evaluation of the tag and use the fallback_tag obtained from
the template.

Change-Id: I1175fe045bd5bc9ddcd9ecbbd13578cee7713a17
Closes-Bug: 1829158

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30384, 'date': '2019-05-16 03:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-05-16 04:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

[{'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-07 17:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-07 17:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25301, 'date': '2018-03-08 08:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-11 08:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-12 13:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-12 13:39:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2018-03-12 13:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24667, 'date': '2018-03-13 10:15:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

1. I think it's no problem for 'Time' and 'Credibility' to be as a merge-rule, but I have some doubt for 'Severity'.
Because the standard of 'Severity' between different monitors may be not consistent. 
For example, Doctor A define 'High' fever for over 38℃, and doctor B define it over 39℃.
Another reason I doubt is that 'OK' never covers 'Error' due to 'OK' is lowest level, which is unreasonable in my view.
2. It's possible for user to define the same 'Credibility' when he didn't know which monitor is more credible at all.
How to decide the 'winner' when 'Credibility' is same? Will the 'Time' become the secondly rule by default? 
Or should we provide user to define several rules, first rule:'Credibility', second rule:'Time', ......"}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-13 11:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> 1. I think it's no problem for 'Time' and 'Credibility' to be as a
 > merge-rule, but I have some doubt for 'Severity'.
 > Because the standard of 'Severity' between different monitors may
 > be not consistent.
 > For example, Doctor A define 'High' fever for over 38℃, and doctor
 > B define it over 39℃.
 > Another reason I doubt is that 'OK' never covers 'Error' due to
 > 'OK' is lowest level, which is unreasonable in my view.
 > 2. It's possible for user to define the same 'Credibility' when he
 > didn't know which monitor is more credible at all.
 > How to decide the 'winner' when 'Credibility' is same? Will the
 > 'Time' become the secondly rule by default?
 > Or should we provide user to define several rules, first
 > rule:'Credibility', second rule:'Time', ......

1. In your 38 vs. 39 degrees example, the solution might be not to merge those two specific alarms. But if two alarms *are* equivalent, then I think that merge by severity is the right approach. Actually, I prefer this approach over merge by time or by credibility. And in any case we can let the user decide about it.

Can you please explain what you meant by the 'OK' never covers 'Error' comment?

2. Good question. Maybe only for 'credibility' rule we can let the user decide on the second-level rule. For time and severity it is not needed."}, {'account_id': 24667, 'date': '2018-03-13 11:51:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

What I mean is about the use case(4.2) in the rst.
"4.2. Nagios reports alarm, Vitrage deduced alarm, Nagios reports OK?"
When user choose 'worst_state' as merge-rule, state is 'warning' in the table, because the level 'OK' is lower than 'warning'.
But I think the final expected result should be 'OK' whatever the merge-rule is.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-13 12:12:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> What I mean is about the use case(4.2) in the rst.
 > "4.2. Nagios reports alarm, Vitrage deduced alarm, Nagios reports
 > OK?"
 > When user choose 'worst_state' as merge-rule, state is 'warning' in
 > the table, because the level 'OK' is lower than 'warning'.
 > But I think the final expected result should be 'OK' whatever the
 > merge-rule is.

I disagree. That's exactly the point in worst_state, that we allow every monitor to make an opinion, including Vitrage. I fact, in our Nokia use cases if there is a deduced alarm we *always* want the final state to be warning, because we think that maybe Vitrage has an additional information that is relevant to this alarm and should not be ignored.

If I understood correctly, since your use case is slightly different, you can use the credibility merge-rule. Is it good enough, or is there a problem implementing your use case?'}, {'account_id': 25301, 'date': '2018-03-13 12:30:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-13 12:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25301, 'date': '2018-03-14 06:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 24667, 'date': '2018-03-14 10:07:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > What I mean is about the use case(4.2) in the rst.
 > > "4.2. Nagios reports alarm, Vitrage deduced alarm, Nagios reports
 > > OK?"
 > > When user choose 'worst_state' as merge-rule, state is 'warning'
 > in
 > > the table, because the level 'OK' is lower than 'warning'.
 > > But I think the final expected result should be 'OK' whatever the
 > > merge-rule is.
 > 
 > I disagree. That's exactly the point in worst_state, that we allow
 > every monitor to make an opinion, including Vitrage. I fact, in our
 > Nokia use cases if there is a deduced alarm we *always* want the
 > final state to be warning, because we think that maybe Vitrage has
 > an additional information that is relevant to this alarm and should
 > not be ignored.
 > 
 > If I understood correctly, since your use case is slightly
 > different, you can use the credibility merge-rule. Is it good
 > enough, or is there a problem implementing your use case?

No problem for us. We will choose 'Credibility' or 'Time' mostly in our case, 'Worst state' may be not fit for us.
Anyway, I agree merge-rule include three dimensions above.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-14 10:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-14 10:18:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> No problem for us. We will choose 'Credibility' or 'Time' mostly in
 > our case, 'Worst state' may be not fit for us.
 > Anyway, I agree merge-rule include three dimensions above.

Great, so this part is done. 

I pushed a new patch set with another requirement that I only thought of this morning: the user should be able to change the equivalence definitions over time.

Another thing - I think that maybe 'merge strategy' is better than 'merge rule'. What do you say?"}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2018-03-14 10:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25301, 'date': '2018-03-15 08:13:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)

> > No problem for us. We will choose 'Credibility' or 'Time' mostly
 > in
 > > our case, 'Worst state' may be not fit for us.
 > > Anyway, I agree merge-rule include three dimensions above.
 > 
 > Great, so this part is done.
 > 
 > I pushed a new patch set with another requirement that I only
 > thought of this morning: the user should be able to change the
 > equivalence definitions over time.
 > 
 > Another thing - I think that maybe 'merge strategy' is better than
 > 'merge rule'. What do you say?

Sure, 'merge strategy' is good. Besides, I still have some questions about the details in use cases."}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2018-03-15 11:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Added a document with entity equivalence use cases

This document should define the functional requirements for blueprints
like merge alarms and merge resources.

Change-Id: Ie65b140607b38c880d0a10b3d63c9d58b49d8b1d

commit_message:
Support Vitrage resources in Heat

The purpose is to automate the auto-healing process that
involves external monitoring, Vitrage alarm deduction and
Mistral workflow execution.

Story: 2002684
Task: 22527

Change-Id: If66248e07a662a225799a2bd3fc88a31d1539021

[{'created': '2019-05-08 09:30:41.000000000', 'message': 'Set up cyborg-tempest-plugin repository

This patch set does the following things:
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to master projects list and gerrit permissions
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to zuul
 * Configure GerritBot to Announce Changes

Change-Id: Ib1c294e99f671baf2647d878f05e62a57015ffa3
'}, {'created': '2019-05-09 07:03:10.000000000', 'message': 'Set up cyborg-tempest-plugin repository

This patch set does the following things:
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to master projects list and gerrit permissions
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to zuul
 * Configure GerritBot to Announce Changes

commit_message:
Set up cyborg-tempest-plugin repository

This patch set does the following things:
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to master projects list and gerrit permissions
 * Add cyborg-tempest-plugin to zuul
 * Configure GerritBot to Announce Changes

Change-Id: Ib1c294e99f671baf2647d878f05e62a57015ffa3
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657766/

commit_message:
Adds private_key parameter in the standard ssh actions

This method allows to specify a private key and avoids its storage
in the filesystem of the executors. This can be used later in
combination of a secrets_retrieve to use keys stored in barbican.

Change-Id: Ide438a7f6d24c8bdc9eb2c82e935fd39a6acc2c6
Closes-Bug: #1806703

commit_message:
Add Python 3.7 support

In order to support Python 3.7, pylint has to be updated to 2.0.0
minimum. Newer versions of Pylint enforce additional checkers which can
be addressed with some code refactoring rather than silently ignoring
them in pylintrc; except useless-object-inheritance which is required to
be silented so that we stay compatible with Python 2.x.

Story: 2004073
Task: 27434

Change-Id: I52301d763797d619f195bd8a1c32bc47f1e68420

redirect should work, we can also go ahead and fix them.

commit_message:
[trivial] use systemctl for service management in Ubuntu

service command is a wrapper for SystemV init scripts.
It's still working, but usage of systemd (systemctl) is more common since Ubuntu 16.04.

Change-Id: I59db9bf29696a1e64cdde322df29ec1a827d7e84

[{'created': '2019-05-03 04:56:49.000000000', 'message': "Remove deprecated SHOW_KEYSTONE_V2_RC config option

SHOW_KEYSTONE_V2_RC is deprecated since Stein release and it's safe
to remove it now.

Keystone v2 support removal will be implementes in a follow up patch.

commit_message:
Remove deprecated SHOW_KEYSTONE_V2_RC config option

SHOW_KEYSTONE_V2_RC is deprecated since Stein release and it's safe
to remove it now.

Keystone v2 support removal will be implemented in a follow up patch.

Change-Id: Ib3098789a3aef47f4f4b84fd56f03376ce2ea96f

the next release.

"}, {'created': '2019-05-14 06:20:58.000000000', 'message': "Bump bandit version

Bandit 1.6.0 changes the behavior of the '-x' option so that it now
supports glob patterns. Update our tox file to use to correctly exclude
test code from bandit scans. This requires bumping our minimum bandit
version.
For additional details, refer to ML Thread[1]

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006116.html

Change-Id: I01b3ee75aa52b2711bacbf26690ce55a4c3f336e

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit 1.6.0

There's a regression[0] in bandit 1.6.0 which causes bandit to stop
respecting excluded directories, and our tests throw a bunch of
violations. Blacklist this version, but allow newer versions as there is
already a pull request[1] to fix it, and I expect it will be included in
the next release.

[0] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/issues/488
[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489
For additional details, refer to ML Thread[1]

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006116.html

Change-Id: I01b3ee75aa52b2711bacbf26690ce55a4c3f336e

commit_message:
Add python37 job

Since we've entered Train and the runtime proposed include py37[1],
we need to include it in gate as well as local env.
This patch adds the support for the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ie9da36e048c8f13f625369b59c8c46eb5673194f

commit_message:
oslo.db: Add https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659170/

MariasDB/Galera cluster server produces an error like:

(1213, u'Deadlock: wsrep aborted transaction')

which is currently not detected properly and, thus, not retried.

Change-Id: I137031bf1374349cd0bbb709002140e2f6122d22

commit_message:
Support Heat auto-healing notifier

The auto-healing notifier works together with loadbalancer_member_health
evaluator.

Presumably, the end user defines a Heat template which contains an
autoscaling group and all the members in the group are joined in an
Octavia load balancer in order to expose service to the outside, so that
when the stack scales up or scales down, Heat makes sure the new members
are joining the load balancer automatically and the old members are
removed.

However, this notifier deals with the situation that when some member
fails, the stack could be recovered by marking the given autoscaling
group member unhealthy, then update Heat stack in place.

Change-Id: I6e92d1fc2125e155bb5068ff2c14fa318b126442

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 07:42:23.000000000', 'message': "Document bootstrap host failure on leap 15

Bootstrap host is relying on hostname ansible module to set
hostname. On Leap 15, we are using /etc/os-release instead of
suse-release, which breaks the platform stdlib on python2 and
python3. There is no intention upstream to patch `platform`,
as this has been deprecated, to accept any workaround SUSE needs
to implement. Instead, it is advised to move to the `distro`
library. Hopefully, Ansible is already moving to this. Because
it's very internal to ansible, ansible vendors-in its own version
of it. When we'll upgrade ansible to 2.8 or above, we should get
an improvement (to be tested), or be able to fix it in Ansible
and in distro.

Without this patch, we don't know how to fix, nor who is
responsible of the fix. This should clarify things.

Change-Id: I4394755fbcc91c56e11037729a7683ff658a9f59
"}]
commit_message:
Document bootstrap host failure on leap 15

Bootstrap host is relying on hostname ansible module to set
hostname. On Leap 15, we are using /etc/os-release instead of
suse-release, which breaks the platform stdlib on python2 and
python3. There is no intention upstream to patch `platform`,
as this has been deprecated, to accept any workaround SUSE needs
to implement. Instead, it is advised to move to the `distro`
library. Hopefully, Ansible is already moving to this. Because
it's very internal to ansible, ansible vendors-in its own version
of it. When we'll upgrade ansible to 2.8 or above, we should get
an improvement (to be tested), or be able to fix it in Ansible
and in distro.

Without this patch, we don't know how to fix, nor who is
responsible of the fix. This should clarify things.

Change-Id: I4394755fbcc91c56e11037729a7683ff658a9f59

messages: [{'account_id': 29466, 'date': '2019-05-08 09:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-05-10 07:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-05-15 23:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-08 09:27:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix kolla permissions errors inside nova_virtlogd

[stack@win1 ~]$ sudo podman logs nova_virtlogd
+sudo -E kolla_set_configs OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system

The reason is the following nova_virtlogd bind mount:
 ... - /etc/libvirt/qemu:/etc/libvirt/qemu:ro

Seems kolla config has a some empty folders that are then copied to a
:ro fs and we fail:
()[root@win1 /]$ find
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

Since the above empty folders are due to the timestamp
change caused by the default.xml file removal, let's do
those on BM only.

Hopefully compute folks can propose a more definitive fix that
takes that default.xml removal logic into host-prep-task (if it
is still needed)

Tested on a RHEL8 OS/Containers combo and the error is gone:
[root@overcloud-novacompute-0 ~]# podman logs nova_virtlogd 2>&1| tail -n5
++ chmod 755 /var/log/kolla/libvirt
++ chmod 644 /var/log/kolla/libvirt/libvirtd.log
Running command: '/usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf'
+ echo 'Running command: '\''/usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf'\'''
+ exec /usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf

Change-Id: I629e9e37aff9a1610df874b46c7a5b1eedd3e374
Closes-Bug: #1819482
(cherry picked from commit 7643761601a89823efee9bbbd92f2d05106fc129)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla permissions errors inside nova_virtlogd

[stack@win1 ~]$ sudo podman logs nova_virtlogd
+sudo -E kolla_set_configs OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system

The reason is the following nova_virtlogd bind mount:
 ... - /etc/libvirt/qemu:/etc/libvirt/qemu:ro

Seems kolla config has a some empty folders that are then copied to a
:ro fs and we fail:
()[root@win1 /]$ find
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

Since the above empty folders are due to the timestamp
change caused by the default.xml file removal, let's do
those on BM only.

Hopefully compute folks can propose a more definitive fix that
takes that default.xml removal logic into host-prep-task (if it
is still needed)

Tested on a RHEL8 OS/Containers combo and the error is gone:
[root@overcloud-novacompute-0 ~]# podman logs nova_virtlogd 2>&1| tail -n5
++ chmod 755 /var/log/kolla/libvirt
++ chmod 644 /var/log/kolla/libvirt/libvirtd.log
Running command: '/usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf'
+ echo 'Running command: '\''/usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf'\'''
+ exec /usr/sbin/virtlogd --config /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf

Change-Id: I629e9e37aff9a1610df874b46c7a5b1eedd3e374
Closes-Bug: #1819482
(cherry picked from commit 7643761601a89823efee9bbbd92f2d05106fc129)

Cap sphinx for py2 to match global requirements

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped Python 2.7 support. This is aligned with
[1] in requirements project.

commit_message:
Remove bandit from lower-constraints

The version of bandit in lower-constraints (1.4.0) does
not match the version in test-requirements (1.6.0) however
bandit is a test-only dependency and there is no test coverage
for bandit in the lower-constraints tox job target, so there
is really no good reason to have bandit in lower-constraints.
As such, this change simply removes it from lower-constraints.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I35f66994e9a3a334b342232587d84491542da755

[{'created': '2019-05-13 15:17:08.000000000', 'message': "Fix retry of instance_update_and_get_original

_instance_update modifies its 'values' argument. Consequently if it is
retried due to an update conflict, the second invocation has the wrong
arguments.

A specific issue this causes is that if we called it with
expected_task_state a concurrent modification to task_state will cause
us to fail and retry. However, expected_task_state will have been popped
from values on the first invocation and will not be present for the
second. Consequently the second invocation will fail to perform the
task_state check and therefore succeed, resulting in a race.

Closes-Bug: #1821373
Change-Id: I01c63e685113bf30e687ccb14a4d18e344b306f6
"}, {'created': '2019-05-13 16:45:52.000000000', 'message': "Fix retry of instance_update_and_get_original

retried due to an update conflict, the second invocation has the wrong
arguments.

A specific issue this causes is that if we called it with
expected_task_state a concurrent modification to task_state will cause
us to fail and retry. However, expected_task_state will have been popped
from values on the first invocation and will not be present for the
second. Consequently the second invocation will fail to perform the
task_state check and therefore succeed, resulting in a race.

We rewrite the old race unit test which wasn't testing the correct
thing for 2 reasons:

1. Due to the bug fixed in this patch, although we were calling
   update_on_match() twice, the second call didn't check the task state.
2. side_effect=iterable returns function items without executing them,
   but we weren't hitting this due to the bug fixed in this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1821373
Change-Id: I01c63e685113bf30e687ccb14a4d18e344b306f6

commit_message:
Fix retry of instance_update_and_get_original

_instance_update modifies its 'values' argument. Consequently if it is
retried due to an update conflict, the second invocation has the wrong
arguments.

A specific issue this causes is that if we called it with
expected_task_state a concurrent modification to task_state will cause
us to fail and retry. However, expected_task_state will have been popped
from values on the first invocation and will not be present for the
second. Consequently the second invocation will fail to perform the
task_state check and therefore succeed, resulting in a race.

We rewrite the old race unit test which wasn't testing the correct
thing for 2 reasons:

1. Due to the bug fixed in this patch, although we were calling
   update_on_match() twice, the second call didn't check the task state.
2. side_effect=iterable returns function items without executing them,
   but we weren't hitting this due to the bug fixed in this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1821373
Change-Id: I01c63e685113bf30e687ccb14a4d18e344b306f6

commit_message:
Add /v2 to mistral api endpoint.

whitout the /v2 openstack cli is not able to list workflows, it always
end in 404.

with /v2 both mistral cli and openstack client can be used.

Depends-on: I7770c5417feacfc43a3ad8801125603a55ba9ea8
Change-Id: I80d4fe2441b0a1137aac05fc6ff739cdfefa204d
(cherry picked from commit 8abe36115a2694f4ae1748f28f51b46861002bf4)

commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: I5729d4a3062f767f74b053611410a716091ceb34

messages: [{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-10 15:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-14 10:08:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-05-14 21:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-05-16 00:08:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-10 15:27:30.000000000', 'message': "Add integrated coverage

Currently this role doesn't test the integrated jobs.
While this role isn't immediately exercised (the playbook
is skipped), it is good enough to add coverage of the templates,
should we adapt the template in a global fashion.

Additionally, it is a problem to have different jobs
for SUSE support, as we want to use the integrated jobs template
as a mean to get consistent across roles, so that
it's easier to monitor jobs.

Change-Id: I7502be20bec4243f607087b6f74d20b1ff11a4d5
"}, {'created': '2019-05-14 10:08:37.000000000', 'message': "Add integrated coverage

Currently this role doesn't test the integrated jobs.
With the dynamic execution of the roles, this role
also get tested by the integrated repo.

Change-Id: I7502be20bec4243f607087b6f74d20b1ff11a4d5
"}]
commit_message:
Add integrated coverage

Currently this role doesn't test the integrated jobs.
With the dynamic execution of the roles, this role
also get tested by the integrated repo.

Change-Id: I7502be20bec4243f607087b6f74d20b1ff11a4d5

subject: Remove keystone directory on source installs
messages: [{'account_id': 290, 'date': '2019-05-10 14:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 290, 'date': '2019-05-13 12:48:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-05-14 21:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-05-16 00:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-10 14:14:32.000000000', 'message': 'Remove keystone directory on source installs

Current behavior only attempts to remove the keystone
directory from the first container and skips
additional containers past the first one.  This
caused upgrades to break as the configs were
still present in any additional containers.

This ensures the keystone directory is removed on
all keystone containers when the install method is
is source.

Change-Id: If588f9ed4bc5d0deeb2b9c1bbeea5e9eb5ce7c79
(cherry picked from commit 08ccd4745c63483d912f4ab5364e6345046793a7)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove keystone directory on source installs

Current behavior only attempts to remove the keystone
directory from the first container and skips
additional containers past the first one.  This
caused upgrades to break as the configs were
still present in any additional containers.

This ensures the keystone directory is removed on
all keystone containers when the install method is
is source.

Change-Id: If588f9ed4bc5d0deeb2b9c1bbeea5e9eb5ce7c79
(cherry picked from commit 08ccd4745c63483d912f4ab5364e6345046793a7)

commit_message:
Add ability to specify multiple search domains

Especially when deploying in an environment where we are deploying
into a subdomain, we need the ability to specify multiple search
domains to be added to /etc/resolv.conf.

Related-Bug: #1828854
Change-Id: I45231fc53c24e1aad3f4a0026696954096430586
(cherry picked from commit 98e561a4d28f0e662abe0f32e27284bd8a5b3276)

commit_message:
Add ability to specify multiple search domains

Especially when deploying in an environment where we are deploying
into a subdomain, we need the ability to specify multiple search
domains to be added to /etc/resolv.conf.

Change-Id: I45231fc53c24e1aad3f4a0026696954096430586

commit_message:
Enable setting domain parameter for interfaces

This enables the setting of a static domain that will be used to aid DNS
queries.

commit_message:
Updated from generate-constraints

The following are held back for the reasons noted below:

-grpcio===1.20.1
+grpcio===1.15.0
  tooz has a cap that needs to be removed (most likely)
-SQLAlchemy===1.3.3
+SQLAlchemy===1.2.18
  general breakage in tempest-full https://review.opendev.org/651591
-urllib3===1.25.2
+urllib3===1.24.3
  requests has a cap, they don't seem to care
  https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/5067
-tornado===5.1.1;python_version=='2.7'
+tornado===4.5.3;python_version=='2.7'
  we generate the wrong version for py27
-kubernetes===9.0.0
+kubernetes===8.0.1
  openshift has a hard lock on ~8
-jsonschema===3.0.1
+jsonschema===2.6.0
  caps in the following, all are openstack, so we just need to make sure
  they have been uncapped and schedule releases
  python-ironiclient tempest taskflow python-zaqarclient warlock
  python-solumclient glance-store python-designateclient os-net-config

Change-Id: I48a34d95e6b831c557ed3bb4bab00e6af3d74dbc

[1] in requirements project.

commit_message:
Enable setting domain parameter for interfaces

This enables the setting of a static domain that will be used to aid DNS
queries.

Related-Bug: #1828854

commit_message:
Run puppet 6 unit for Stein and master

We want to test puppet 6 for Stein changes and
for master. Also updates the puppet version
from 6.0.x to 6.4.x which is the latest minor release
for puppet 6.

Change-Id: I18b84f009d1826d45f01d483f57a5c1806565d35

[{'created': '2019-05-11 18:14:29.000000000', 'message': 'Remove nova::network::neutron::neutron_url

This parameter is deprecated and will be removed in [1].

Removing this will make nova use the default behavior of
looking up the endpoint for talking to neutron. Deployments
that want to override that behavior can set the
neutron_endpoint_override parameter or the use the
neutron_valid_interfaces parameter to let nova know what
type of endpoint type to use.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658400/

Change-Id: Id892bf2a2998cb11a5337f36ff55a05dc1f34601
'}]
commit_message:
Remove nova::network::neutron::neutron_url

This parameter is deprecated and will be removed in [1].

Removing this will make nova use the default behavior of
looking up the endpoint for talking to neutron. Deployments
that want to override that behavior can set the
neutron_endpoint_override parameter or the use the
neutron_valid_interfaces parameter to let nova know what
type of endpoint type to use.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658400/

Change-Id: Id892bf2a2998cb11a5337f36ff55a05dc1f34601

[{'created': '2019-05-12 18:17:00.000000000', 'message': "Add retry for backup get_url task

As CentOS aria2 package is still only in epel-testing repo,
get_url tends to fail with timout errors, which forces to do rechecks
and creates extra load on gates.
So we're adding retries for this task and extending timeout.

Change-Id: I26d3c9338247ffc789bf4a5291e65e954151cc51
(cherry picked from commit 1b1078aca96a1cc22ccaab335c0159b3bf5fa9a5)
"}]
commit_message:
Add retry for backup get_url task

As CentOS aria2 package is still only in epel-testing repo,
get_url tends to fail with timout errors, which forces to do rechecks
and creates extra load on gates.
So we're adding retries for this task and extending timeout.

Change-Id: I26d3c9338247ffc789bf4a5291e65e954151cc51
(cherry picked from commit 1b1078aca96a1cc22ccaab335c0159b3bf5fa9a5)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 23:01:22.000000000', 'message': "Remove infra trusty puppet jobs

Upstream puppet deleted package repos and while we can install the
puppet-agent packages directly from the archive this requires working
SNI which we don't have by default on trusty. trusty is eol and we've
almost completely deleted all of our trusty nodes so lets just remove
these test jobs.

Change-Id: I12f33d81e7119dedf94fac9c26a0a867cdc940df
"}]
commit_message:
Remove infra trusty puppet jobs

Upstream puppet deleted package repos and while we can install the
puppet-agent packages directly from the archive this requires working
SNI which we don't have by default on trusty. trusty is eol and we've
almost completely deleted all of our trusty nodes so lets just remove
these test jobs.

Change-Id: I12f33d81e7119dedf94fac9c26a0a867cdc940df

commit_message:
[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I296dd05d675cc23f1aebe606edf5e175fa4b6208

commit_message:
[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

commit_message:
Add microversion in header for Senlin

Senlin webhooks are now compatible with Aodh's notification API as of
microversion 1.10. We must send this in the header to use this
microversion. See Senlin commit 0d2db

Change-Id: Ia65ec5bc241d72f0fe45d7106d5a53283f29d25d

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit also adds python 3.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ib60a6fb08590e5a90244b7d09bece153f6e4a970

commit_message:
Stop leaving temp files after unit test runs

test_shell.CLOUD_2 is using an absolute path for a temp
file, so leaves /tmp/test_log_file around after the unit
tests are run.  Use a fixture instead so it's cleaned
automatically, which also removes the possibility of two
tests using the same file and interfering with each other.

Change-Id: If722b860be4010b91635c6d46f634da980e17152

commit_message:
Create a tool for recreating missing metrid_id in Cassandra

In some rare cases it is possible for a row in Cassandra for
metrics to have no value for metric_id or created_at, though
they may still have updated_at and the other required columns.

This tool is for recreating the metric_id from the other required
columns.

An additional 'persister-check-missing-metric-id.py' tool is
provided which can be run to see if there are missing metric-id
values that need to be recreated.

Please see the README.rst for usage directions.

Story: 2005305
Task: 30611

Change-Id: I0593558407c8c773d728bbd035dde91310b59be3
(cherry picked from commit 09af9bff91e5a109d5bcd204f3647aa4fe023fe9)

commit_message:
Fix nova-grenade-live-migration run book for opendev migration

Commit 76418a32cbbcc3ecc3a89bc3ebb0ecc767046da0 was not taking
the opendev rename migration into account so the nova-grenade-live-migration
job fails. This fixes it using the same changes to the run book from
the stable/rocky commit: cf435a9450bfe8a72d7cac7d1307237574862d08.

Change-Id: I668575053810d6a43a077d10d84f6a723419f438

commit_message:
Add safety check output to the linters output

Currently a safety check failure is ignored, the output
is just for informational purposes. it reports known
security issues with the versions in upper-constraints.txt
so that we can determine a corrective action.

Change-Id: Ib8191602f47641eb047ebe5972ffa92bcfd08de4
(cherry picked from commit b628986912f4cb312c74ff22c1a6370df81bc8d8)

commit_message:
Add safety check output to the linters output

Currently a safety check failure is ignored, the output
is just for informational purposes. it reports known
security issues with the versions in upper-constraints.txt
so that we can determine a corrective action.

Change-Id: Ib8191602f47641eb047ebe5972ffa92bcfd08de4
(cherry picked from commit b628986912f4cb312c74ff22c1a6370df81bc8d8)

commit_message:
Add docs for image type support request filter

This adds the missing "prefilter" stage to the description of the
scheduling process, and adds information about the image type
filter.

Related to blueprint request-filter-image-types

Change-Id: I07eef048cf2c85a3fdb8adbe38e362878e4e177e

commit_message:
Enable image type query support in nova-next

This enables the scheduler support for asking placement to filter computes
with support for the given image's disk_format.

Related to blueprint request-filter-image-types

Change-Id: I07e0e6b26d01d3b481c74693bb1948ed82ceebd6

I really really like request filters. They make use of placement in a nice tidy sane happy way.

I think there may be a debugging leftover in the new test.

commit_message:
Add image type request filter

This enables the scheduler, if configured, to limit placement results
to only computes that support the disk_format of the image used
for the request.

Change-Id: I41511365eb2b76c4cad804445766638a92b68378

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit also adds python 3.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I2841c18c889a788a88e4ec50e7daa15109b2e6bc

messages: [{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-10 03:53:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-05-10 07:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-05-15 21:27:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-10 03:53:36.000000000', 'message': "[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I215dc9bca6eb586b9c18c85f29a644ef25de41ea
"}]
commit_message:
[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I215dc9bca6eb586b9c18c85f29a644ef25de41ea

[{'created': '2019-04-14 19:24:16.000000000', 'message': 'Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I05823bdccc2747ab2bdf2adc26b5e702f6dce332
'}]
commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I05823bdccc2747ab2bdf2adc26b5e702f6dce332

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-25 11:31:52.000000000', 'message': "Add workers' type check before launching the services

If user set the type of worker to str or others, there will
be no error here, but a lot of processes will be created,
which may cause the system to crash.

I recommend adding a type check here.

Change-Id: I3ad0f7ec59f29a3106d23b057327c3dfef19a98f
"}, {'created': '2019-05-05 01:09:12.000000000', 'message': "Add workers' type check before launching the services

commit_message:
Add workers' type check before launching the services

If user set the type of worker to str or others, there will
be no error here, but a lot of processes will be created,
which may cause the system to crash.

I recommend adding a type check here.

Change-Id: I3ad0f7ec59f29a3106d23b057327c3dfef19a98f

subject: WIP: include_tasks vars in ansible 2.7
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8175, 'name': 'Rafael Folco', 'email': 'rfolco@redhat.com', 'username': 'rfolco'}, {'_account_id': 8297, 'name': 'Sofer Athlan-Guyot', 'email': 'sathlang@redhat.com', 'username': 'chem'}, {'_account_id': 8449, 'name': 'Marios Andreou', 'email': 'marios@redhat.com', 'username': 'marios'}, {'_account_id': 9592, 'name': 'wes hayutin', 'email': 'whayutin@redhat.com', 'username': 'weshayutin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26343, 'name': 'Jose Luis Franco', 'email': 'jfrancoa@redhat.com', 'username': 'jfrancoa'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8175, 'date': '2019-05-06 18:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8175, 'date': '2019-05-07 17:08:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2019-05-08 08:46:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

could you please add a little of context in this review? I'm trying to find a change in the include_tasks module in 2.7, but I can see that the way to apply a set of tags in the included tasks is via args: apply: -> https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/include_tasks_module.html

- name: Apply tags to tasks within included file when using free-form
  include_tasks: install.yml
  args:
    apply:
      tags:
        - install

With this change I believe we're treating the tags as if it was a variable being passed to the tasks, which is not the case."}, {'account_id': 8175, 'date': '2019-05-13 14:28:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

> could you please add a little of context in this review? I'm trying
 > to find a change in the include_tasks module in 2.7, but I can see
 > that the way to apply a set of tags in the included tasks is via
 > args: apply: -> https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/include_tasks_module.html
 > 
 > - name: Apply tags to tasks within included file when using
 > free-form
 > include_tasks: install.yml
 > args:
 > apply:
 > tags:
 > - install
 > 
 > With this change I believe we're treating the tags as if it was a
 > variable being passed to the tasks, which is not the case.

Right. I got stuck trying to find a replacement for tags. I know these cannot be treated as vars, so I'll have to find out a better way to bump to newer ansible without breaking our tags functionality."}, {'account_id': 8175, 'date': '2019-05-15 20:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

definitely this is the wrong direction. Ansible 2.7.10 works with tags under include_tasks. For some reason https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655938/ is failing on containers-multinode job.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 18:47:37.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: include_tasks vars in ansible 2.7

Change-Id: I8b3f2d47763654c4285833ac99a1f2b66b978d79

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-31783 : SUCCESS in 3h 23m 19s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-15 20:18:07.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

No longer going to use this, see details in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/633293/30/nova/compute/manager.py@4475 but in summary we can't do this without updating the volume attachment with the dest host connector to get the connection_info to pass to this method in the virt driver, but we can't update the attachment on the dest host if there is already a connected attachment for the volume on the source host, and trying to work around that is complicated and something that could fail with normal (same cell) resize today. So rather than bend over backwards to try and do this pre-validation for cross-cell resize I'm just going to drop it since if we're going to do it we should arguably do it for normal resize as well (or all move operations really)."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-30 22:51:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add can_connect_volume() compute driver method

This adds a method to the ComputeDriver interface
and implementation for the fake and libvirt
drivers. This method is meant to be used as a way
for the ComputeManager to determine if a given volume
can be connected on the host.

This will be leveraged during cross-cell resize
pre-validation checks to ensure volumes attached to
the server in the source cell can also be connected to
the target host in the target cell.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Idb33f4c077242d93ce91936edd0294bf1d3b1fdc

commit_message:
Add can_connect_volume() compute driver method

This adds a method to the ComputeDriver interface
and implementation for the fake and libvirt
drivers. This method is meant to be used as a way
for the ComputeManager to determine if a given volume
can be connected on the host.

This will be leveraged during cross-cell resize
pre-validation checks to ensure volumes attached to
the server in the source cell can also be connected to
the target host in the target cell.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Idb33f4c077242d93ce91936edd0294bf1d3b1fdc
